justification: The paper discusses that post-error slowing is traditionally measured by calculating the difference between average reaction time post-error and post-correct for each participant, indicating a positive value for post-error slowing.

Post-error speeding is identified when there is a negative value in the difference between average reaction time post-error and post-correct, as seen in certain conditions of Notebaert et al's Experiment 1.
The data from Experiment 2 showed a significant slowing of post/win RT due to the presence of direct feedback, suggesting that decision time modulation occurs following positive outcomes.
